div1.p: IN THE CIRCUIT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES, FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON.
In the Matter of:
The application of Antwine Michel for a Writ of Habeas Corpus
PETITON FOR WRIT
To the Honorable C.H. Hanford, Judge:
The petition of Antwine Michel respectfully shows to Your Honor:

That he is now and imprisonment detained and confined in custody of the United States Marshal for the District of Washingon, in the City Jail of the City of Spokane, and within the District of Washington, for a supposed criminal offense against the laws of the United States.

Your petitioner further avers, That he is committed and held by the said Marshal in the said Jail aforesaid by virtue of a Process and warrant of Commitment issued by J. W. Marshal, United States Commissioner for the District of Washington, residing at Spokane; that on the 12th day of January, A. D. 1898, one Felix Pugh, a deputy Marshal, upon oath, did charge that on the 29th day of December, 1898, and within the limits of the Colville Indian Reservation, your said petitioner, being then and there an Indian, did, with a knife, unlawfully and feloniously assault another Indian named John Whil-Ochen, and did the said John Whil-Ochen then and there cut and wound, whereof the said John Whil-Ochen did not die. That a copy of the Warrant of Commitment by which your petitioner is held is hereto annexed.

And your petitioner further avers, That he is not held for, or charged with, any other different crime against the laws
of the United States, and is not held or detained for any other reason save as set forth herein.

Your petitioner further avers, That he is advised by his Counsel, F. C. Robertson, Esq., residing at Spokane, Washington, and so believes, that his said imprisonment is illegal, and that said illegality consists in this, to-wit:

That the said place at which the said cutting and wounding took place for which the petitioner was arrested, is not within the limits of the Colville Indian Reservation, as the same now is set apart, designated and created by the laws of the United States, but the said crime, if committed at all, was committed upon the public domain outside of the limits of said Colville Indian Reservation; That the said place where the said crime was committed, if committed at all, was wholly within the limits of the County of Stevens and of the State of Washington. That the place where the said difficulty occurred between your petitioner and the said Indian John Whil-Ochen was at a point northerly from the town of Marcus, Stevens County, Washington, and on the northern bank of Kettle River, aboout nine (9) miles from the said town of Marcus and at a point along which the public road passes from said town of Marcus to the town of Grand Forks, British Columbia. That the said point and place where the said difficulty occurred, under the laws of the United States and the decisions of this Court, has been held to be and is within the exclusive jurisdiction of the County of Stevens, Washington, for all purposes of civil and criminal jurisdiction; and the said place and point is not within the exclusive jurisdiction of the United States of within the jurisdiction of the United States whatever;
W H E R E F O R E , Your petitioner prays for a Writ of Habeas Corpus to the end that he may be discharged from custody.

Antwine Michel
Petitioner.

F. C. Robertson
Counsel for petitioner.

United States of America, )
District of Washington, ) SS.

Antwine Michel, being duly sworn, on oath deposes and says: That he is the petitioner mentioned in the foregoing petition subscribed by him; that he has read the same and knows the contents thereof and that the statements made therein are true, as he verily believes.
Antwine Michel
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 28 day of Janurary, 1898

F. C. Robertson
Notary Public.
IN THE Circuit COURT of the United States
NINTH JUDICIAL CIRCUIT– DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON DIVISION
In the matter of the Application of Antwine Michel, for a writ of Habeas Corpus
Plaintiff
Petition.
Defendant

FILED Jan. 29 1898
IN THE CIRCUIT COURT
A. Reeves Ayres
HM Walthew
Deputy
F. C. ROBERTSON
Spokane Washington
Attorneys for petitioner
United States Circuit Court for the District of Washington.
In the matter of the application of Antwine Michel for a writ of Habeas Corpus

Plaintiff
vs.
Defendant

No. 655
PRAECIPE FOR APPEARANCE
To the Clerk of the above entitled Court:
You will please enter my appearance as atty for petitioner in the above entitled cause.
F. C. Robertson
div1.fw: NOTICE-- Attorneys will please endorse their own Filings. Rule 47.
div1.p: ifp.Tx

United States Circuit Court
DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON

In re
Antwine Michel

Plaintiff
vs.
Defendant
Praecipe for Appearance.

Filed January 29, 1898,
A. Reeves Ayres Clerk
HM Matthew
Deputy Clerk.
For
IN THE CIRCUIT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES, DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the Matter of The Application of Antwine Michel for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
ORDER.

Now on this 29th day of January, 1898, on reading and filing the petition of Antiwine Michel, it is ordered by the court that C. W. Ide, United States Marshal, who is in said petition alleged to have the said Antwine Michel in his custody, do appear before this court, at the court room in the City of Seattle, on the 31st day of January, 1898, at the hour of 10 o'clock A. M. , then and there to show cause if he can, why a writ of Haveas Corpus should not issue, as prayed for in said petition.

C. H. Hanford
Judge.
Tx.

THE THE Cir COURT
OF THE UNITED STATES
FOR THE
DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON

In re –
Antwine Michel
vs.
Order to show cause

Filed January 29, 1898,
A Reeves Ayres Clerk
By HM Mattheew Deputy

Jan 29
Issued cert
In the Circuit Court of the United States for the District of Washington, Northern Division.

In re- Antwine Michel,
Petitioners Ex parte,
The court having ordered a writ of Habeas Corpus to issue herein, to the Marshal of the United States for the District of Washington,

Now comes the Attorney of the United States for the District of Washington and states to the court that the offense with which petitioner is charged was not committed at any place within the jurisdiction of the United States Courts, but was committed in the County of Stevens in the State of Washington, in that certain territory formerly embraced in the North half of the Colville Indian Reservation in said county, which was relinquished from said reservation and restored to the public domain by the act of Congress of July 1, 1892.
And moves the court to order the said Marshal to deliver the body of said petitioner to the sheriff of said Stevens County to be dealt with according to the laws of the state of Washington,

And the court having heard said motion and carefully considered the same, the court finds the facts stated to be true, and sustains said motion. It is therefore ordered and adjudged that the said Marshal notify the said Sheriff of Stevens County, Washington, of this order, and upon demand of said Sheriff, said Marshal shall deliver to said Sheriff the body of said petitioner, but if no such demand be made within five day then aid Marshal release said petitioner from custody.

C. H. Hanford
Judge.

IN THE Cir COURT
OF THE UNITED STATES
FOR THE
DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON

In re–
Antwine Michel
vs.
Order.

Filed January 31 1898
A Reeves Ayres Clerk
By HM Matthew Deputy
In the Circuit Court of the United States, Northern Circuit, District of Washington
In the maters of the Application of Antwine Michel for a writ of Habeas Corpus

Comes now the petitioner herein and excepting to the return of the Marshal for the insufficiency hereby moves this honorable court for an order delivering the this hereto of petitioner notwithstanding the said return of the U. S. Marshal

F. C. Robertson
Attorney for petitioner
Tx.
U. S. Circuit Court
In re Antwine Michael on habeas corpus
Exception and motion
Filed Jan 31 1898

IN THE
U. S. CIRCUIT COURT
A. Reeves Ayres.
Clerk By R. M. Hopkins
Deputy
IN THE CIRCUIT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES, DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Application of Antwine Michael for a writ of habeas corpus/
Answer and Return upon the Order.
To the Honorable Cornelius H. Hanford, Judge:

Comes now C. W. Ide, United States Marshal for the District of Washington, and for his answer and return upon the order issued by this Honorabe Court upon the petition of Antwine Michael, begs leave to say:

First. Respondent, C. W. Ide, Marshal as aforesaid, is compelled to inform this Honorable Court that he has no personal knowledge of the matters and things set forth in petitioner's petition. This petition was filed in this Honorable Court late Saturday afternoon, January 29th, 1898, and the order issuing from this Court did not come to the possesion of respondent until this morningm thus respondent having been informed, however, by F. S. Robertson, attorney for petitioner, on Saturday last that such petition would be filed, and being advised by telegram Saturday night that the same had been done and the order issued made returnable this morning. Respondent further says that the petitioner, Antwine Michael, is now in custody at Spokane, as respondent has been informed. That there has not been sufficient time to gather from the records the absolute facts in the case, and this answer is therefore made upon information and belief, for the reason that respondent cannot answer in any other wise.

Second. Respondent further answering says, that it is his information and belief that the petitioner, Antwine Michael, is an Indian and a ward of the United States Government, being under control of an Indian-Agent, to-wit, one Anderson upon the Colville Reservatoin, within the jurisdiction of this Court, and that he, the said Antwine Michael, did sometime on or about the latter part of December last past with a deadly weapon feloniously and purposely make an assault upon the person
-1-
of one John Whil-Ochen, another Indian ward of the United States, belonging to a tribe of Indians unknown to this respondent, byt being under the control and charge of the said Indian Agent Anderson, on the said Colville Reservation, within the jurisdiction of this Court. This respondent has been advised and believes the fact to be that said assault was so made upon and within the limits of the Colville Indian Reservation, heretfore established by executice order dated July 2nd, 1872. Whether said assualt was committed upon what is known as the North half of said Reservation, as stated in petitioner's petition, your respondent has no information or belief.

Third. Respondent further answering says, that pursuant to the commission of said assault in the manner as aforesaid, that one Felix M. Pugh in due and legal form made complaint in writing before one J. W. Marshal, United States Commissioner for the District of Washington, duly appointed and acting and residing at Spokane, who thereupon, on the 12th day of January, 1898, issued his warrant of arrest for him, the said Antwine Michael, which said warrant of arrest was delivered into the hands of a Deputy United States Marshal, who, in obedience to the command of said warrant, did arrest and apprehend the said Antwine Michael in all respects according to law, and that it is in pursuance of these proceedings that he, the said Antwine Michael, is now in the custody of this respondent or his authorized deputy at Spokane. That all the proceedings thereon were in due and legal form and that the said Antwine Michael has not been discharged by the said Commissioner upon hearing, or by any other person having authority so to do after inquiry and hearing in the manner as provided by law, and neither has the said Antwine Michael sought to have said hearing.
Having fully justified the said order, respondent herein asks that he be discharged and the petition for habeas corpus be dismissed.

Wilson R. Gay
United States Attorney.

C. W. Ide
Respondent.
No 665
In U. S. C. Court
In the matter of the Appln of Antoine Michael for writ Habeas Corpus
Return and Answer

Filed Jan. 31 1898
U. S. Circuit Court
A Reeves Ayres
Clerk.
HM Matthew
Deputy.
Wilson R. Gay U. S. Atty
In the Circuit Court of the United States for the Ninth Circuit, District of Washington ,
In the matter of the application of Antwine Michel, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus. :

And now this cause coming regularly on for hearing upon the answer of Clarence Ide, United States Marshal, to the rule to show cause why a writ of Habeas Corpus should not issue herein, as prayed for by the petitioner, and the matters and things therein set forth beig fully considered, and the court being fully advised in the premises, it is ordered that a writ of Habeas Corpus do issue as prayed for.

C. H. Hanford
Judge.
Tx.
GoB .5-rrt
No 655

IN THE Cir. COURT
OF THE UNITED STATES
FOR THE
DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON

In re
